questions.question: What is the empirical formula of UTSA-62?
At what temperature and under what atmosphere is UTSA-62 thermally stable up to?
What is the BET surface area of UTSA-62a?
What is the maximum excess H2 uptake of UTSA-62a at 3.8 MPa and 77 K?
What is the total CO2 adsorption of UTSA-62a at 298 K and 8 MPa?
What is the isosteric heat of adsorption of CO2 for UTSA-62a compared to other adsorbents?
What is the significance of the low isosteric heat of adsorption of CO2 for UTSA-62a?
questions.answer: It leads to lower regeneration costs.

questions.question: Why is UTSA-62a considered highly porous?
questions.answer: Because of its BET surface area of 2190 m2 g(cid:3)1 and a total pore volume of 0.91 cm3 g(cid:3)1.

questions.question: How does UTSA-62a perform in high-pressure CO2–CH4–H2 separation compared to zeolites and other MOFs?
questions.answer: UTSA-62a shows moderately high productivities and lower regeneration costs, making it competitive.

questions.question: What makes UTSA-62a suitable for H2 purification under high pressure?
questions.answer: Its high porosity and weak interactions with carbon dioxide.

questions.question: Is UTSA-62a's structure robust?
Does UTSA-62a have a higher CO2 adsorption capacity at lower temperatures?
Is the regeneration cost of UTSA-62a higher than that of MgMOF-74?
Can UTSA-62a be used for drug delivery applications?
Does UTSA-62a exhibit type-I adsorption behavior for N2?
Is the H2 productivity of UTSA-62a at high pressure significantly lower than the best performing MOFs?
Does UTSA-62a have specific binding sites on the pore surfaces for interactions with CO2?
What is the role of the dendritic hexacarboxylate organic linker in UTSA-62a?
questions.answer: It plays a role in stabilizing the framework.

questions.question: What is the crystallographic space group of UTSA-62?
What is the dimension of cage A in UTSA-62?
